notesStmt.note: Any special notes on this text? (optional)

sourceDesc.p: Information on named entities in this file has been extracted from files in the Digital Mitford Archive.

person.note: Mentioned in Francis Needham’s biographical listings of people in Mitford’s circles or relevant to her work.

Solicitor at various addresses in Lincoln Inn Fields, London; and at Friar Street, Reading. He was an articled clerk in Abingdon. Prominent citizen of Reading. Spouse of Mrs. Newbery. Name variously spelled Newbery and Newberry. He was sued for fraudulent handling of a client's money and subsequently declared bankrupt in 1835. Source: Reports of Cases Argued and Determined in the English Courts of Common Law, vol. 31 (1853): 62-63.

item.name: wisteria
Wisteria
Wisteria
Fabaceae
item.note: Group of woody climbing vines bearing cascading purple flower plumes, native to Asia and to the eastern US. The North American variety was catalogued in 1817; wisterias began to be imported into Europe and the UK as garden plants in the early nineteenth century. They are usually grown supported by walls, fences, or pergolas.

item.name: azalea
Rhododendron
Ericaceae
item.note: Flowering shrub carrying abundantly showy red, pink, or white blooms in spring, related to rhododendrons. Grow in the understory of woodlands, and have been hybridized as garden shrubs for hundreds of years. Native to Eurasia and North America. Introduced to the UK in the 19th century as a garden ornamental, it is now considered an invasive species.

item.name: rhododendron
Rhododendron ponticum
Rhododendron
Ericaceae
item.note: Flowering shrub carrying abundantly showy round flower clusters in shades of mauve or lavender blooms in spring, related to azaleas. Grow in the understory of woodlands, and have been hybridized as garden shrubs for hudreds of years. Native to Eurasia and North America. Introduced to the UK in the 18th century as a garden ornamental, it is now considered an invasive species.

item.name: cottongrass
Eriophorum angustifolium
Eriophorum
Cyperaceae
item.note: Sedge that develops fluffy white heads.

item.name: heart's-ease
Viola tricolor
Viola
Violaceae
item.note: Wild pansy native to the UK.

item.name: common snowdrop
Galanthus nivalis
Galanthus
Amaryllidaceae
item.note: Small white-flowered plant propagated by bulbs, native to Europe and the Middle East and widely naturalized elsewhere. Believed to be native to the UK since the 16th century. Flowers in late winter and early spring, around the vernal equinox and so is considered a harbinger of spring. May also symbolize purity, hope, or the Christian Holy Trinity. A frequent subject of 19th century poetry including works by Landon and Wordsworth.

item.name: hepatica
Anemone hepatica
Anemone
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Low-growing flowering plant with fleshy leaves and blue, purple, or pink flowers with showy white stamens. Flowers in late winter and early spring. Native to Europe and Asia and grown as a garden plant as well as naturalized in the UK.

item.name: winter aconite
Eranthis hyemalis
Eranthis
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Tuberous, low-growing yellow flowering plant native to Europe and naturalized in the UK. One of the earliest woodland wildflowers, appearing in late winter. Unrelated to aconitum (monkshood).

item.name: fuchsia
fuchsia magellanica
fuchsia
Onagraceae
item.note: Small upright or spreading flowering shrub, with showy, pendulous bi-colored blooms in combinations of red, pink, purple, and white sepals and petals. A large genus, native to the Carribbean islands, Mexico, central and South America. Now a widely grown garden shrub and pot plant. F. coccinea and F. magellanica, both from South America, were being cultivated in England by the late eighteenth century. Vineyard Gardens in Hammersmith, England introduced fuchsias to the gardening public, as well as introducing and popularizing imports such as the China rose and dahlia as garden plants.

item.name: garden mignonette
Reseda odorata
Reseda
Resedaceae
item.note: Tall, thin pale yellow flower spike growing from base leaves. Native to Europe, the Mediterranean region, and southwest Asia. In the 19th century, grown in gardens and windowboxes for its fragrance. Also used in perfumery, potpourri, and as a cut flower in arrangements. R. luteola, another species, was a source of yellow dye.

item.name: hop-bines
Humulus lupulus
Humulus
Cannabaceae
item.note: Twining plant using stiff, hairy stems (bines) to climb. Flowers of the female plants are the source of hops, used in brewing to flavor beer.

item.name: common wallflower
Erysimum cheiri
Erysimum
Brassicaceae
item.note: Flowering plant native to the Mediterranean basin and widely used as a garden plant for its showy, fragrant clusters of yellow-orange racemes.

item.name: common myrtle
Myrtus communis
Myrtus
Myrtaceae
item.note: Evergreen flowering shrub bearing white flowers with many showy white stamens and dark blue edible berries. Native to the Mediterranean region and western Asia to India. Associated with Jewish, Greek, and Roman ritual and myth, symbolizing honor, prosperity, hope, and love. In early-modern Europe, the flowers became traditional in bride's bouquets because of their associations with love and happiness.

item.name: common buttercup
Ranunculus acris
Ranunculus
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Perennial wildflower of medium height with small, shiny yellow flowers with prominent green or yellow sepals. Native to Eurasia but widely naturalized elsewhere.

item.name: ranunculus
Ranunculus asiaticus
Ranunculus
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Single-flowered red wildlflower with cup-shaped flowers, native to the Mediterranean region. Hybridized double-flowered forms in a variety of colors are used as garden plants, grown from tubers, and as cut flowers in floristry.

item.name: lavender
Lavandula angustifolia
Lavandula
Lamiaceae
item.note: Medium-height evergreen flowering shrub with narrow leaves and pale purple flowers, native to the Mediterranean. Despite the common name English lavender, it not native to the UK. Grown as a garden plant, the flowers as a medicinal and culinary herb, and its aromatic oils are used in perfumery and massage.

item.name: orchid
orchis
Orchidaceae
item.note: Flower plant member of the large family of the Orchidaceae, which contains nearly thirty thousand species and more than 100, 000 hybrids and cultivars. 52 types of orchids are native to the UK and are most common in the South of England; these include the ghost orchid, lady's slipper, red hellebore, greater butterfly orchid, early spider orchid, green-winged orchid, lady orchid, and fly orchid. Tropical species have been grown in the UK in glasshouses since the 19th century and are also cultivated for sale at florist's shops, as corsages, cut flowers, or pot plants. Scented varieties may be used in perfumery; and vanilla bean pods, with culinary uses, derive from an orchid species. 19th c. Europe and the UK saw a craze for collecting and hybridizing wild orchid species collected from elsewhere, called orchidelirium, orchidomania or orchid fever, similar to the 17th-century Dutch tulip mania.

item.name: convolvulus
Convolvulus arvensis
Convolvulus
Convolvulaceae
item.note: One of numerous species of vines with trumpet-shaped flowers.

item.name: celery
Apium graveolens
Apium
Apiaceae
item.note: Both wild celery and the cultivated variety are the same species. Wild varieties grow in wetlands and are most noticeable for their parsley-like leaves and white flower stalk. Cultivated varieties are grown for their fibrous stalks and their seeds, which are used as a spice. It is thought to be native to the Mediterranean region, and has been cultivated since antiquity, in winter and early spring. Further hybridization by the 19th century had extended the growing season, and celery became an increasing important raw and cooked vegetable in British, American and European cuisines.

item.name: potato
Solanum
Solanum tuberosum
Solanaceae
item.note: Potatoes are relatively new to Europe at this time. They are native to the Andes and were introduced only in the second half of the 16th century by the Spanish.

item.name: turnip
Brassica rapa rapa
Brassica
Brassicaceae
item.note: Grown for its fleshy root, for consumption by both humans and livestock. Other subtypes of the same plant are grown for their stems or leaves, including: bok choy and rapini. In the UK and parts of North America, the term is also used to refer to rutabagas or swedes, a larger root vegetable in the same family.

item.name: asparagus
Asparagus officinalis
Asparagus
Asparagaceae
item.note: Flowering perrenial plant whose young shoots are cultivated as a vegetable. Native to Eurasia, the subspecies Asparagus officinalis subsp. prostratus is believed to be native to coastal western Europe, north Ireland, and Great Britain.

item.name: moss
item.note: Nonvascular, low-growing plants that prefer damp soils, part of the large group of byrophytes. More than one thousand varieties live in the UK. UK mosses include: common haircap, silky forklet, Swan's-neck thyme, common tamarisk, glittering wood, and common striated feather-moss.

item.name: fern
Pteridium aquilinum
Pteridium
Dennstaedtiaceae
item.note: A genus of large, sturdy ferns, common throughout the world. It may be the most adaptable and oldest group of ferns. Commonly found on moorlands and hillsides and may form dense thickets of fronds, spread through its creeping roots. In the UK, moorland types are called moorland scrub. Traditionally gathered for use in leather tanning, soap- and glass-making, and for use as livestock bedding. Today, it may be seen as a threat to biodiversity, as its spread can elbow out other ground-cover plants upon which animals and other plants depend, and decrease the size of open moorlands.

item.name: field mushroom
Agaricus campestris
Agaricus
Agaricaceae
item.note: A gilled mushroom, commonly eaten, and closely related to the cultivated button mushroom.

item.name: gentianella
xxx
Gentianella
Gentianaceae
item.note: UK varieties include the early gentian (Gentianella anglica) and Chiltern gentian (Gentianella germanica).

item.name: marsh marigold
Caltha palustris
Caltha
Ranunculaceae
item.note: Medium-sized plant in the buttercup family that prefers marshes, wetlands, and wet woodlands. Known by many different regional names in the UK in addition to marsh marigold and kingcup.

item.name: stock
Matthiola incana
Matthiola
Brassicaceae
item.note: Group of more than fifty types of tall, spike-flowered plants in the Brassica family and may refer more specifically to Matthiola incana. Flowers may be a variety of colors ranging from white through pink and purple. Cultivated scented varieties are UK garden favorites.

item.name: tuberose
Polianthes xxx
Polianthes
Asparagaceae
item.note: A perennial plant that is frequently used in perfumes.

bibl.author: Charles Lamb
bibl.title: The New Style of Acting
The Works of Charles Lamb: Critical Essays

bibl.author: Charles Lamb
bibl.title: The Works of Charles Lamb: Critical Essays
Weston Grove: A Descriptive Poem [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Narrative poem

bibl.title: On an Intended Removal From a Favourite Residence. November, 1820 [1827 version]

bibl.note: Sonnet 20 in the 1827 collection (page 314). Also appeared in the 1822 New Monthly Magazine (page 81) signed M.

bibl.title: Written After a Visit From Some Friends [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
On Visiting Donnington Castle [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 18 in the 1827 collection (pages 311-12). Also appeared in the 1821 New Monthly Magazine as Sonnet on Visiting Donnington Castle(page 532).

bibl.title: Written in a Friend's Album [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 17 in the 1827 collection (page 310). Also appeared in Marshall's Christmas Box in 1831.

bibl.title: On Leaving a Favourite Picture [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 16 in the 1827 collection (page 309). Appeared in the 1821 New Monthly Magazine as Sonnet. On a Landscape by Mr. Hofland(page 392). Later appeared in the 1827 Literary Souvenir (page 233).

bibl.title: To a Friend on Her Birthday [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 15 in the 1827 collection (page 308). Also appeared in the 1822 New Monthly Magazine (page 369) signed M.

bibl.title: The Fishing-Seat, Whiteknights [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 14 in the 1827 collection (page 307). Also appeared in the 1827 Literary Souvenir (page 287).

bibl.title: On Hearing Mr. Talfourd Plead in the Assize-Hall at Reading, On His First Circuit, March 1821 [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 13 in the 1827 collection (page 306).

bibl.title: On Two of Mr. Hofland's Landscapes [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 12 in the 1827 collection (page 305).

bibl.title: New Year's Day. 1819 [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 11 in the 1827 collection (page 304).

bibl.title: Englefield House [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 10 in the 1827 collection (page 303).

bibl.title: To Mr. Haydon, On a Study From Nature [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 9 in the 1827 collection (page 302). Also appeared in the July 19, 1817 Literary Gazette as To Mr. Haydon dated 21st May, 1817 (page 41).

bibl.title: To Miss Porden: On Her Poem of COEUR DE LION [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 8 in the 1827 collection (page 301). Also appeared in the August 17, 1822 Literary Gazette under the same title, dated June 10, 1822 (page 519).

bibl.title: On a Beautiful Woman [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 7 in the 1827 collection (page 300). Also appeared in the 1822 New Monthly Magazine as Sonnet. (page 192).

bibl.title: To My Mother Sleeping [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 6 in the 1827 collection (page 299).

bibl.title: Written July, 1824 [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 5 in the 1827 collection (page 298).

bibl.title: To Mr. Henry Richardson. On His Performance of Admetus in the Alcestis of Euripides as Represented in the Original Greek at Reading School [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 4 in the 1827 collection (pages 296-97).

bibl.title: The Forget-Me-Not [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 3 in the 1827 collection (page 295).

bibl.title: On Mr. Hofland's Picture of Jerusalem at the Time of the Crucifixion [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 2 in the 1827 collection (page 294). Also appeared in the 1826 Amulet as Sonnet: Jerusalem (page 329).

bibl.title: Written in a Blank-Paper Book Given to the Author by a Friend [1827 version]
Dramatic Scenes, Sonnets, and Other Poems
bibl.note: Sonnet 1 in the 1827 collection (page 293). Also appeared in the 1821 New Monthly Magazine as Sonnet. Written in a Blank Paper Book Given To the Author by a Friend(page 387).
